ygData.msgSnippet: Hi German, ... I m not really sure how this can be achieved. The proposed dialect describes genomes of the structure used by traditional NEAT. If other types

Hi German,

German Viscuso wrote:

>I've followed the XML thread (and I've seen the file proposed-neat.xml), it
>seems to me that
>two general features are important for the standard:
>
>-Neutral standard for indirect and direct encoding.
>  
>
I'm not really sure how this can be achieved. The proposed dialect 
describes genomes of the structure used by 'traditional' NEAT. If other 
types of *genome* (as opposed to phenome) are to be used then an XML 
dialect will need to be described for each one - and that can then be 
combined with the more generic parts of the XML such as search 
parameters along with an identifier that describes which type of genome 
structure is being used in a particular XML file.

>-Support dynamic addition of domains tags (as proposed by Colin).
>
>  seems necessary and straight forward since people like you Derek
>are working with indirect encoding; I'm not sure if supporting both type of
>encodings may generate some kind of conflicts in the standard (seems not to
>be a problem).
>The second is a little more delicate because I think domain specific tags
>may get out of control and make the standard useless.
>
>  
>
I guess you can think of the dynamic tags as the providing some 
flexibility to the fixed 'standard' XML. Long term it would be nice if - 
as with the genome structure - each type of domain and evaluation scheme 
had it's own sub-dialect defined that could be inserted into the XML and 
be identified by an ID.  However, whilst a structure is being 
experimented with it's nice not to have it pegged to an XML dialect, 
simply because it becomes one more thing to update whenever you want to 
change things. So think of the dynamic tags as being there to support 
experimentation.

>Right now I do not have more specific comments until I start using the
>proposed xml template (in about 15 days).
>
>So far I think it looks good.
>
>  
>
Thanks. All feedback is gratefuly received :) 

Colin.
